title: Terry Carr's Best Science Fiction and Fantasy of the Year 16
text:
Terry Carr's Best Science Fiction and Fantasy of the Year #16 is an <a href="anthology">anthology</a> of <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> short stories edited by <a href="Terry%20Carr">Terry Carr</a>, the sixteenth and last volume in a <a href="The%20Best%20Science%20Fiction%20of%20the%20Year">series</a> of sixteen. It was first published in hardcover by <a href="Tor%20Books">Tor Books</a> in September 1987. The first British editions were published in hardcover and paperback by <a href="Victor%20Gollancz%20Ltd">Gollancz</a> in December of the same year, under the alternate title Best SF of the Year #16.
The book collects eleven novellas, novelettes and short stories by various science fiction authors, with an introduction, notes and concluding essays by Carr, <a href="Charles%20N.%20Brown">Charles N. Brown</a>, and <a href="Beth%20Meacham">Beth Meacham</a>. The stories were previously published in 1986 in the magazines "<a href="Asimov%27s%20Science%20Fiction">Isaac Asimov's Science Fiction Magazine</a>", "<a href="Playboy">Playboy</a>", "<a href="The%20Magazine%20of%20Fantasy%20%26amp%3B%20Science%20Fiction">The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction</a>", and "<a href="Analog%20Science%20Fiction%20and%20Fact">Analog Science Fiction and Fact</a>", and the collection "<a href="Blue%20Champagne%20%28book%29">Blue Champagne</a>".
Awards.
The anthology placed third in the 1988 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Anthology</a>.
"Escape from Kathmandu" was nominated for the 1986 <a href="Nebula%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novella">Nebula Award for Best Novella</a>, the 1987 <a href="Asimov%20Reader%27s%20Poll%20for%20Best%20Novella">Asimov Reader's Poll for Best Novella</a>, the 1987 <a href="Hugo%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novella">Hugo Award for Best Novella</a>, and the 1987 <a href="SF%20Chronicle%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novella">SF Chronicle Award for Best Novella</a>, and placed second in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novella</a>.
"Hatrack River" was nominated for the 1986 <a href="Nebula%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novelette">Nebula Award for Best Novelette</a>, the 1987 <a href="Asimov%20Reader%27s%20Poll%20for%20Best%20Novelette">Asimov Reader's Poll for Best Novelette</a>, the 1987 <a href="Hugo%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novelette">Hugo Award for Best Novelette</a>, and the 1987 <a href="SF%20Chronicle%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novelette">SF Chronicle Award for Best Novelette</a>, won the 1987 <a href="World%20Fantasy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novella">World Fantasy Award for Best Novella</a>, and placed second in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novelette</a>.
"Blindsight" placed fifteenth in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Short Story</a>.
"Aymara" was nominated for the 1986 <a href="Nebula%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novelette">Nebula Award for Best Novelette</a>, won the 1987 <a href="SF%20Chronicle%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novelette">SF Chronicle Award for Best Novelette</a>, and placed seventh in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novelette</a>.
"Cold Light" placed twenty-first in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novelette</a>.
"Surviving" was nominated for the 1986 <a href="Nebula%20Award%20for%20Best%20Novelette">Nebula Award for Best Novelette</a>, won the 1987 <a href="Theodore%20Sturgeon%20Award">Theodore Sturgeon Memorial Short Story Award</a>, and placed twenty-eighth in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novelette</a>.
"The Prisoner of Chillon" won the 1987 <a href="Asimov%20Reader%27s%20Poll%20for%20Best%20Novelette">Asimov Reader's Poll for Best Novelette</a> and placed twenty-third in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Best Novelette</a>.
"And So to Bed" placed fourteenth in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Short Story</a>.
"Grave Angels" placed twenty-seventh in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novelette</a> and was nominated for the 1987 <a href="Theodore%20Sturgeon%20Award">Theodore Sturgeon Memorial Short Story Award</a>.
"Tango Charlie and Foxtrot Romeo" placed third in the 1987 <a href="Locus%20Award">Locus Poll Award for Best Novella</a>.
